degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Science with Italian as a major

mot.qual: I worked in Italy, speak french and adore Italy as a county. The other subjects I take would very much benefit from having two languages, especially in a career sense. I'd love to study and work in Italy in the future.
advantages.qual: Language is irrevocably connected with culture, and having access to another language really gives an insight into another culture and way of living as a whole. Being a native speaker of English is a bit of a blessing and a curse. Yes, we speak what is probably the most important language in the world at the moment, however unlike people of other countries we have way less incentive to actually become bi-lingual, so it sort of perpetuates on itself and I just see English speakers becoming perpetually more mono-lingual, which is a shame and really limits the way we can see the world. Obviously having a second language is great on a job-prospect level, but it's also something that I think is really important for me on a personal level.
idealfuture.qual: Hopefully it'll allow me to work in Italy! If not, which honestly is likely, the physical act of speaking another a language is actually really fun and something I've learnt to enjoy heaps from studying french for years.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Diploma of Languages (Italian)

mot.qual: I have grown up being exposed to elements of Italian culture and feeling that being Italian is part of my identity. Learning Italian would allow me to speak to my Nonna more easily and make me feel more Italian in general, something that's important to me because I really enjoy learning about and kind of honouring my heritage.
advantages.qual: I think being bilingual is really useful in today's society. Although I'm really enjoying my Arts degree, sometimes I can't help but fear that it won't be at all useful in getting a job, since it's getting more and more difficult nowadays. Since English is so widely spoken I feel that there will be a demand for it overseas, and if I know Italian as well I'll have an edge, so I'll hopefully have an advantage in getting a job after uni.
idealfuture.qual: I would like to do exchange in Italy or maybe even live there for some time, so Italian would be imperative then. As mentioned, I can also imagine Italian playing a role in my future career, I could work over there or I could get a job that requires me to speak to Italian people here in Australia etc.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Diploma of Languages (Italian)

mot.qual: I am currently studying a masters in art curatorship and have developed a strong interest in late medieval cultural production in Europe, in particular Italy.  I have travelled to Italy on several occasions and have spent over 2 moths there during the past two years.  Studying Italian strengthens my qualifications as an art museum professional/art historian.  It will hopefully expand my work opportunities and enable me to contribute more fully to research in my field of art history and curatorship.
advantages.qual:
The main advantages of studying Italian at University level for me are


I will have stronger qualifications in my field - recognised as more expert.
I will be more confident when communicating and researching in Italy as I have been taught to a high standard. 
I will have a more nuanced understanding of Italian culture.
Ultimately I will have increased agency within Italy when researching.
idealfuture.qual: Italian has a critical role in my future.  It will solidify my place as a professional in my field and possibly give me an advantage over others.  It opens up a range of work opportunities for me in varying fields within my area of study e.g. museums/universities/auction houses in many different countries around the world.
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)

mot.qual: I have always wanted to learn a european language and university is offered the opportunity. I have traveled to Italy before and love the culture and language, so that is why I specifically chose Italian. I am not from Italian heritage.
advantages.qual: Studying language at a university level gives students the opportunity to be emersed in the language and culture of Italy without being there.
idealfuture.qual: I hope to travel in the future, and perhaps live and work in Italy for a while.
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)
other.degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Environments with Diploma of Languages (Italian)

mot.qual: A desire to broaden the Society I can interact with.
advantages.qual: In my opinion Language is the main, or most apparent, facilitator of Human thought, so studying any such at a University Level is to me the closest one can get to, in a literal sense, gaining a new perspective on the world. Italian specifically is a language with a rich literary and historical tradition alongside it's modern use, thus studying it at a University level better facilitates the opening of that different perspective, contrasted to say Albanian or Indonesian.
idealfuture.qual: I'm planning to go on exchange in July to Bologna, so most immediately It'll help me get the most out of that experience and make connections that would otherwise be impossible. Also in helping me reconnect with my family and roots in Italy, they're from Campagna, something I've wanted to do since I was young. Further in my future career, I'm currently working towards diplomatic roles and hopefully one day working in the United Nations, a body in which knowledge of any language is not a wasted skill.
study.other.L2: I studied beginner Arabic, and Ancient Egyptian language.
origins.specify: My great-grandmother fled the rise of Fascism in the south of Italy during the 20's with her parents, being from an aristocratic family.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a major

mot.qual: I already speak three languages fluently and I wanted to become fluent in a fourth language, so I chose Italian. I love the language, Italian culture, food and history, even though I am not Italian or of Italian origin myself. I would like to be able to teach Italian after completing my degree.
advantages.qual: Personally, I believe that studying any foreign language at university level is something that has many advantages. Although Italian is not known to be one of the most popular or widely-spoken languages around the world, I chose to study Italian at university level purely because I love the culture, the country, and the language. My decision to study Italian as a major will enable me to work with the language in a professional setting - I would like to teach Italian in the future.
idealfuture.qual: Italian is very important for me as it is one of my majors. Ultimately, it is my goal to be able to teach English, French, Greek and Italian (Italian is the only language that I do not speak fluently yet). In order to do this, I am trying my hardest to immerse myself in the language as much as possible on a daily basis in order to reach my goal by the end of my studies: becoming a teacher of Italian.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Diploma of Languages (Italian)

mot.qual: I have continued to study Italian at university level because it helps with my communication skills. For example, it will help me speak the language more confidently in Italian-speaking countries and within Italian communities.
advantages.qual: Learning Italian at university level means I can stand out from the crowd in the job market. Studying a language at university is seen as very cultured and being very open minded, meaning that I will be a more successful candidate when being employed.
idealfuture.qual: I would like to do exchange in Bologna. Also, I can become a more confident person knowing another language, as my communication skills will significantly develop.
study.other.L2: Japanese but I'm not going to continue learning it
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a major

advantages.qual: Not sure yet - ofcourse I will be able to do an exchange to Italy and make the most of it as I have a certain level of proficiency in the language.
idealfuture.qual: Not sure.

idealfuture.qual: Italian will assist me in travelling overseas, particularly to Europe. A knowledge of Italian will allow me to interact with Italian people and locals that I may meet. It will also enable me to build stronger connections with family members who communicate primarily in Italian.

mot.qual: To be able to speak another language.

advantages.qual: I believe that Italian is viewed as an incredibly attractive language in the sense that it is one of the 'romantic' languages closely related to its Latin ancestor. When someone possesses the skill of speaking in Italian people also view that person as having access to the expansive culture that the Italian language gives way to.
idealfuture.qual: I plan to travel a lot to Italy in the future and in particular see relatives in Italy. I also believe that becoming a translator is definitely a possible goal of mine that would be amazing to reach.

mot.qual: To master the language in a way that I never could by learning in secondary schools, watching Italian TV or having conversations with my Italian dialect-speaking family. I'm also learning at the most respected institution in the country for studying Italian, which makes me want to see just what the best is. So far I've learned a lot more slang and swear words than my peers, and in Italian that's important.
advantages.qual: The opportunities. Business with Italians (I write and would like to be able to translate), kinship with Italian speakers, overhearing conversations in Lygon St or in Northcote supermarkets, the exposure to all kinds of Italian media and the enrichment that brings, being able to do more things and go more places in Italian communities. My family in Italy also enjoy the novelty of a young Australian speaking their language.
idealfuture.qual: Italian friends and business, books and TV. Hopefully Italy will make more podcasts.

mot.qual: I commenced studying it in high school and took to it well, as it was the only language offered at my school. My decision to continue studying Italian in university felt like a necessity, as I did not want to lose my connection with the language.
advantages.qual: It allows me to access a more academic side to my brain rather than the creativity I apply to my Bachelor of Music.
idealfuture.qual: I would just like to be a casual speaker of the language and have the ability to visit Italy with a comfortable fluency. It doesn't directly apply to my career, although I believe it will give me a certain confidence with my status as a bi-lingual person and of the freedom I hope to have when travelling in Europe.

advantages.qual: learning another language gives you greater awareness and understanding of how your own language works. As I am also studying creative writing this is an important skill for me. I also think (hope) that by learning Italian I am escaping the stereotype of the lazy English speaker
idealfuture.qual: I would like to live in Italy at least for a period of my life. I am very interested in the art and culture of such an old society.

mot.qual: I really love languages, in general, but also im particularly attracted to the idea of being able to communicate with people in other languages. For me, this love is applicable to many languages, but learning italian happens to be my first goal.
advantages.qual: i would say gaining the ability to communicate in another language. i dont place much status upon english, other than its sheer convenience because it is such a common, widespread language
idealfuture.qual: I definitely don't see learning italian as something that will advance my career in future (although i certainly wouldnt be complaining if this were the case). for me, italian is a language i will be able to read, write and express myself in, hopefully allowing me easier travel through italy one day.
degree.roleL2: NA

mot.qual: When I was 15, I went on student exchange to Italy. I went to Italy because I wanted to go on exchange, I didn't go on exchange because I wanted to go to Italy specifically. I'm not Italian and I don't have any Italian heritage. I chose Italy because I had it as a subject as my school (though wouldn't say I had any actual knowledge of the language before I left). I then continued studying Italian because I wanted to, but also because my continued study of it was a condition of my going away. I have always been interested in languages and do really enjoy continuing to study Italian.
advantages.qual: As much of an advantage as it is speaking English as a first language, I also think it's a bit sad the way English speakers never feel they need to learn another, as well as a bit obnoxious (especially if you're spending any extended amount of time in a non-English speaking country). I think it's an important way to broaden your horizons and look at things from a different perspective/through a different filter. I also think for me personally, being someone of a generation who were never taught grammar at school, it has assisted me immensely with that. As far as studying it specifically at university, I haven't really considered any that are really applicable to my life.
idealfuture.qual: I want to be about to communicate in Italian fluently, though the only real practical application of it that I see is so I can show people I met that can speak Italian now :) Maybe I'd like to work in Italy someday, perhaps teaching English, in which case speaking Italian would be useful, however there's no specific reason I want to study it for my future, other than the satisfaction of having learnt it and not given it up.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a minor

mot.qual: It is a skill that I know I will have for the rest of my life, and will be relevant to whatever I wish to do, be that work related, or for travel. I want to do more travel, and for me, the ability to connect to a place and to people through the language that they speak is important, and enriches the experience.
advantages.qual: For me, I don't necessarily think of clear advantages, since I am learning it not for a career necessarily, but more for a personal interest. An advantage to me is that I will be able to communicate with more people, travel in Italy speaking Italian, having a more well rounded experience. Allows the possibility of becoming part of a larger community, both internationally and in Australia. In addition, having learnt Italian will be a great advantage when/ if I do exchange.
idealfuture.qual: In the near future I would love to do an exchange in Italy, having the chance to live completely differently for a long period of time. In terms of career, I think it would be amazing at some point to live and work in Italy, just because I love the country so much, but I have no specific career goals which will be assisted by my learning Italian. For me, it's important to engage with a community larger than Melbourne and Australia.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Diploma of Languages (Italian)

degree.roleL2: NA

mot.qual:
I am very passionate about languages and have a strong desire to being able to speak another language fluently. 

I really enjoy speaking Italian, but find it quite frustrating when there's something that I don't know how to say, so I'm studying it with the hope to improve my fluency. 

I like studying it because I enjoy how the language sounds. 

I feel a connection to Italian through classical music, which uses a lot of Italian terminology.
advantages.qual:
I'm  not really sure that there are that many advantages to learning Italian per se, as it's not a world language like English. Understanding another culture and language definitely gives you empathy to people of all different backgrounds, and there are cognitive benefits to being bilingual as well. 

Knowing Italian would allow me to live and work in a place where Italian is spoken, or interact with people of Italian backgrounds in a workplace environment; but in an Australian context, I only really see myself using it, in a non-social way, in a language teaching context.
idealfuture.qual: I'm not sure, but I know that would like to be using Italian in my future and not forget the language.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a breadth subject.

mot.qual: I want to translate Carla Lonzi.

Being able to communicate with people from different cultural backgrounds.
Gaining access to spaces and thus to people and experiences that would otherwise be restricted.
idealfuture.qual: It supports my career as a translator.

mot.qual: My main motivation for studying Italian is the ability to be able to speak it fluently so that when travelling, visiting family in Italy or even studying in Italy, it will become almost second nature to me. I also hope to maybe work in Italy or in Europe one day, and have dreams of becoming multilingual, with Italian being my first choice as I love learning it and being able to communicate with my relatives in their language.
advantages.qual: I think just the ability to speak another language is amazing and being able to do that as it is very challenging is something to be really proud of. I think learning Italian at university level opens us up to the culture, history and life of Italians which would otherwise be unknown as it is not widely spoken about here in Australia. For me, also being able to communicate with my family in Italy is a major advantage. I believe that when employees see that you can speak multiple languages, they see this as a good thing as it is not easy to learn languages and this is another advantage of learning a language such as Italian at university level.
idealfuture.qual: I hope to have a career that allows me to speak English, Italian and whichever other languages I may learn in the future. Also, in the future, if I travel to Europe as I hope to, I'd love to speak good Italian in Italy to get the whole experience. Italian in my future also allows me to communicate with my family in Australia who speak the language and also in Italy whose English skills may be lacking or quite non existent.
origins.specify: My dad, paternal grandparents and maternal grandfather all were born in Italy and speak dialects of the language.

advantages.qual: I have a much greater knowledge of not only the language but the culture of the country. This makes me feel more worldly. You study the language and culture to a much more complex level which enables you to experience your reality on a deeper level. Learning Italian also causes me to question my English grammar when speaking which results in an improvement of English. There are many similarities with Italian and Spanish, so I am also able to understand certain sentences in Spanish and compare the word differences.
idealfuture.qual: In my future, I intend on being able to speak and understand the language. I will use this when travelling, and will regularly watch Italian movies to maintain my understanding of Italian. I don't intend on dedicating my career to teaching or studying Italian, however if my science pathway leads me to Italy, knowing how to communicate in Italian will be of great advantage.

mot.qual: My main motivation for studying Italian is because of my love of the Italian culture. I have studied it my entire life and when I could not study it, I felt as though a part of my identity had been lost and felt compelled to recommence my studies ASAP.
advantages.qual:
I have a few advantages listed below;
At a university level it helps me to interact with other students that are not part of my faculty/ course. 
At a university level I feel challenged and satisfied when I complete Italian homework/ exam tasks knowing I have put my full effort into it.
At a university level my knowledge of the Italian language as a whole, compared to what I just learnt during the semester/ year/ unit, compels me to study the language in my personal time and can see my knowledge base actually growing year by year.
idealfuture.qual: In my future I aim to be working in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade at an international stage in my career; utilising my English and Italian skills concurrently in my work overseas in foreign embassies. Having knowledge of Italian would not just open up opportunities in Italian speaking countries, but also at a supranational level with the European continent and its (current) opportunities for European Citizens (for clarification I aim to have my European passport in a year's time in order to receive those opportunities).
study.other.L2: I studied Japanese at a university level.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a major

mot.qual: I would like to maintain my Italian skills.

Overall, I chose to study it at university because I am completing a science degree and Italian gives me a fun break from my content heavy other subjects.
advantages.qual: I feel it will develop my world view and my cultural appreciation. I also believe learning a new language gives you an understanding for what it is like for foreigners in our country who don't speak English.

I did not consider Italian as having status. Where I grew up Italians were looked down on as dumb immigrants.
 I consider Spanish and Arabic to be more useful although I also love Greek. I am however interested in Fine Arts and Italian language and culture is interwoven with history there.

It will helps me to live and work more easily in Europe. It could be combined with further study or research at an Italian University.

mot.qual: I hope to travel to Italy and other European countries after university and I would love to be able to communicate with local people in their native tongue. I am learning Italian because I believe the practice of learning a second language challenges your brain to think in ways that other subjects do not. I am also learning Italian because I love the food and culture, and would love further insight into such a vibrant country.
advantages.qual: Learning Italian is challenging for me which I really enjoy. As I am doing a science degree, having Italian as my breadth is a refreshing change and helps me relax and enjoy my course. I believe learning any language is impressive and shows skill and application, something that would be recognised by future employers.
idealfuture.qual: I hope to travel and perhaps work in Italy one day, so being able to speak Italian would be beneficial. I mainly wish to travel to less touristy regions of Italian where English may be less common; I relish the challenge of having to rely on my knowledge to communicate in a foreign language.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Science with Italian as a minor
other.major.minor33: Biology, Chemistry and Fundamentals of Physics

mot.qual:
Since my family is from Calabria, when my Grandparents moved to Melbourne just after the second world ward - along with many others from the south of Italy - their local language came with them. My parents were thus exposed to a version of Italian very much divorced from modern day Italian, and consequently were unable to reciprocate the same learning environment for their children (me) that they group up within. 

I am motivated then to better understand my heritage, connect with relatives and learn true Italian.
advantages.qual: The language is accessible for a beginner as progress is made very quickly, aiding a sense of fulfilment with your tertiary studies.
idealfuture.qual: Italian has a secondary role in my future wherein it will facilitate travel as well as a foster an understanding of my heritage.
origins.specify: Vibo Valentia, Grandparents moved after the second world war to Melbourne.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a minor

degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Diploma of Languages (Italian)

mot.qual: I am half Italian and want to know some of the language. My cousins were raised in a bilingual household (Italian and English) so they can speak to our Nonna in her native language. I'm not upset that I wasn't raised in the same way, but I do wish I knew simple sentences and phrases. My goal isn't to be fluent but to have a broader knowledge.
advantages.qual: Being able to communicate in a language that isn't English would make me feel like I have the ability to communicate with a whole other population. When I've travelled, I feel like a bit of the authenticity is lost because I can only speak English- if i could speak Italian, I could communicate in a way that goes beyond that normal 'tourist' conversation.
idealfuture.qual: Being able to speak Italian would enable me to live/study/work in Italy comfortably, if I ever choose to move there. I have experience working in kitchens, and cooking in an Italian kitchen in Italy is a bit of a dream of mine- speaking the language would obviously help to achieve that.
origins.specify: My dad's parents are both Sicilian- they immigrated here before they had kids. Dad is a first-generation Australian born Italian
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a major

mot.qual: As a Spaniard, I have always considered Italy as "our brother in Europe". Every time I am in Italy I feel at home, since the people are super friendly, the weather is very similar, the landscapes and the food, Mediterranean. When I was in high school, I used to do exchanges with Italians so I visited the country often and made close friends with many Italians. The language is pretty similar aswell, which helps communication.
advantages.qual: I do not think speaking Italian will help me in my career, unless I live in Italy (which I wouldn't mind, for some time).
idealfuture.qual: Probably since I have so many Italian friends, it will help me feel even closer to them. But I do not learn it thinking in a proffessional matter. I just think it is a beautiful language, from a beautiful country and very nice people, that's my motivation.

I plan on going to Italy often in the future as I have many friends in Europe and every year we get together in a small town, an hour from Milan, to enjoy the summer holidays. So I do see Italian playing quite a big role in my life. Understanding the locals, being able to order my own sandwich and being able to talk to my friends in their language are some things that I want to be able to do. I see myself living in Italy for at least a few years.

advantages.qual: Many Italian and English words are similar (except for 'caldo' which means 'hot' - how confusing).

origins.specify: My Nonno, Nonna and two of their kids came over from Italy. They then had six more kids, and the youngest was my father.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a minor

mot.qual:
I am a Chinese student, and I have always wanted to learn a few other languages. I started with English, and now I am thinking of learning Italian, French and Spanish. I will do one at a time, and right now it's Italian. 

Main motivation: interest. The Renaissance started in Italy, and I am obsessed with art and art related history. I want to be able to visit the country that gave birth to the Renaissance one day, speaking the country's language as if I was born there. I don't want to visit a country feeling like I am a foreigner. I wan to go to Italy feeling like I am just visiting an old home of mine. 

Also, I love Italian food. Studying italian gives me confidence when I order food in italian restaurants. Now I am able to take my fiance to all the nicest little italian restaurants and cafes and teach him a few sentences while we have dinner. (feels good man)
advantages.qual:
Learning Italian, going to Italian tutorials is a great opportunity to meet people of similar interests. Many people from my tutorial either have Italian backgrounds or are intrigued with the Italian language and culture. Mixing in with such people gives me a sense of belonging. 

also, as a science student (I am doing physics, chemistry and biology all together), the four hours of Italian tutorial throughout the week is a great "mind refresher" for me. Studying Italian increases my productivity. 

In addition, studying languages is beneficial for brain development and slows down brain ageing, which is advantageous for not just university level, but for a whole life time.
idealfuture.qual: As mentioned before, Italian is a tool. Using this tool, I will be able to travel to Italian, walk on the streets of Florence, Rome and Tuscany, visit all the beautiful places without feeling like a tourist, but feeling like a local. I see myself visiting the art galleries, the cathedrals, the monuments, wearing a pale maxi dress, with an Italian novel in my hands.
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)
other.degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Science with Italian as a breadth

mot.qual: Majority of my family and relatives speak Italian and English, or only Italian, and I really want to be able to communicate with them.

mot.qual: I have many family members who are Italian and I would like to be able to communicate with them in a more meaningful way.
advantages.qual: I will be able to speak to my family members who have limited understanding of English and it also enables me to work in an international company, increasing the flexibility of where I can potentially live and work.
idealfuture.qual: Conversing with family and consequently building stronger relationships as well as allowing me to travel and live in Italy functionally.
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a minor

mot.qual:
I've been surrounded by Italian speakers my whole life, but have never been able to fully understand a conversation or get involved in conversation. Especially as my Nonno and Nonna are getting older I would like to someday be able to converse with them so there is less of a language barrier. Also I have travelled to Italy, and visited relatives and I think it was a shame that my parents could communicate and not myself or my sister, so getting to know other relatives was quite challenging. Also one day I hope to do my own travels with friends, and I would like to be able to speak the language because I am in another country. I feel as though when foreigners come to Australia we expect them to be able to speak our language so why should it be any different the other way around if I were travelling to their country. 

Studying Italian could also allow me to keep my options open, like whether i would like to work over seas or not. Also I have always had an ear for languages, and have previously studied French, and stemming from Latin, they are very similar, and I've easily picked up aspects of the language.
advantages.qual: I think the main advantage is that it keeps my options open for the future, for different types of jobs, like becoming a translator, or tour guide, or even an Italian teacher.
idealfuture.qual: Travelling, communicating with family, working overseas possibly, etc.
speak.other.L2: French, not fluent, but have a fair amount of knowledge
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a major

mot.qual: My initial motivation comes from my heritage. I am a third generation immigrant and my Nanna is bilingual speaking both English and Italian. I find that this is a way for me to connect with a side of my family (both in Australia, Italy and Argentina) on a personal level through writing and speaking Italian and from a general cultural level as well. It excites me to understand Italian lifestyle and people more than I believe I could from an English only perspective. It will allow me to also be more injected and involved, while also developing myself from what the language and culture holds.
advantages.qual: I see the strong advantages of having a birth lottery land me in an English speaking family and society. I think it already has a strong global relevance with its emergence as a global language. However I think people in Australia and other English speakers take this for granted. A mindset and worldview can become very centred on what we can identify and explain with our primary language. Learning Italian at a university level will allow me to gain a greater perspective on the world and my place within it while also gaining insight into an Italian view of the world. I'm glad that it has already connected me with fellow students and staff who are at varying levels of Italian proficiency but all share a desire to learn and develop. It would allow me to extend this community with my family, my friends and my fellows. I hope that it will also be further inspiration for me to visit Italy at the same time as a future in travel and occupation will inspire me to keep learning Italian. I hope to work and study in Italy in the near future and taking classes will add to a sense of fulfilment
idealfuture.qual: Firstly I hope to be able to share a language with my grandparents and relatives. I have never conversed in Italian at a family gather or face to face with a family member since I study away from home. While I'm unsure of my career trajectory my university has many international opportunities. I hope to take an exchange to Fiorenze (go Fiorentina!) or Venezia to continue my course and Italian studies. While there I hope it will allow me to be more of a contributor to Italy than a voyeur. With a genral interest in language and a specific passion for Italian I could see my self in a bilingual career or as a translator/interpreter.
origins.specify: Family from Valenzia - Crespano del Grapa
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)
other.degree.roleL2: International Relations - breadth subject (I think! We have to do four language classes if that helps)

mot.qual: To be able to speak to my Italian family, and to make my self less reliant on family while travelling to Italy.
advantages.qual: I could have learnt Italian privately, but learning Italian at university gives some form of accountability for myself, as performing well directly impacts my GPA and performing poorly has a large impact on me.
idealfuture.qual: The ability to communicate with older family members in Australia, as well allowing me to easily visit my family in Italy and not struggle with communication.
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)
other.degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Information Technology with business as a minor. Italian is a student elective.

mot.qual: Reconnect with my heritage. I always wanted to communicate effectively with my grandparents and relatives and would love to honor their memory by learning the language and culture I love.
advantages.qual: I believe that language is best learnt with others. The point of language is to communicate and this is not a solo activity. By studying at university it allows for a group environment with the advantages of recognition of learning.
idealfuture.qual: I have relatives in Italy and Australia that I would love to better communicate with. I love traveling and hope to use my Italian skills in the near future.
origins.specify: Father's Parents migrated to Australia from Italy.
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)
other.degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Software Engineering with Diploma of Languages

mot.qual: I want to learn more about the culture and all that is is connected to,and that it influences. I'm really interested in art and music history, which Italy has played a major part in. I also just love visiting the country, and hope to gain a better understanding, or at least ability to communicate with the local Italian community, intrinsic to Melbourne's character and development.
advantages.qual: I think it may set me up for a more considerate approach to studying cultures in general, as it has proved to me just how ignorant it can be to assume things about another culture, and reminds me that my perspective is Australian-based and not a neutral basis for comparing or analyzing other cultures, particularly as places like Italy are much, much older and have long been globally influential and interactive.
idealfuture.qual: I hope it allows me more communication with Italian speakers, as I would like  to assist transitioning migrants and refugees. I would also just like to be able to socialise with people from other cultures without them having to put in all the effort for communication. Additionally, I would love to travel around Italy as well, and potentially stay for a while, and definitely visit many art galleries, museums, and historical sites, both there, and in other places where Italian works and language are referenced (so pretty much everywhere and anywhere, really!).
degree.roleL2: Bachelor of Arts with Italian as a minor

mot.qual: Initially, it was (and still is) to be able to communicate with relatives and friends in Italy who never learnt to speak English. Now I would love to eventually teach English in Italy.
advantages.qual: I believe it can help me with a teaching career in the future, and allow me to connect with and learn from people from other parts of the world.
idealfuture.qual: Most importantly, I will be able to communicate properly with relatives whom I have met but was not able to have a very great conversation with. It plays mostly a communication role.
degree.roleL2: Other (please specify your degree and whether Italian is a major, minor or breadth subject)
other.degree.roleL2: Deferred Bachelor of Arts, though continuing with Italian

idealfuture.qual: I would like to be able to speak Italian and hopefully pass that ability down generations like my family has done.

mot.qual: I really like Italian popular music and I like Roma. I hope I can have a chance to live there to know more about Italy.
advantages.qual: I think the main advantages for me is I've improved myself, I can speak anther language.
idealfuture.qual: Currently, I can not imagine, because I am still not really learned well, and I must need to learn more and more, practice more and more to master the language, it's takes a long long time. And I would work for that.
